data.title: The Best Dutch Wingers
data.meta_description:
How would you rank them?

Sjaak Swart
Coen Moulijn
Piet Keizer
Rob Rensenbrink
Johnny Rep
Ren√© van de Kerkhof
Marc Overmars
Arjen Robben

Any notable...
data.text:
To give a meaningful answer:

The following wingers appeared in the top 100 of Dutch footballers composed by Henk Spaan (a Dutch football journalist).

98 Peet Petersen

97 John van 't Schip

96 Rinus Bennaars (inside-left; famous in Holland for containing Pele in a match when used as defender, an unusual position for him)

90 Jo Bonfrere

89 Henk Schouten (an inside-forward though, but not a pure striker)

82 Jan Mulder (a great striker but used as a right-winger for the national team, if he played)

81 Frans Bouwmeester (a natural left-winger but when he moved to Feijenoord and Coen Moulijn came along he became an inside-left)

77 Coen Dillen (all-time goalscorer in a single season in the Eredivisie, hi managed this feat as a right-winger)

74 Henk Wery (the right-winger of the European Cup winning team of 1970)

72 Tscheu la Ling

71 Mick Clavan (for 17 consecutive years a national team player)

67 Gerard 'Pummie' Bergholz (a left-winger but Feijenoord had already Coen Moulijn so he moved to the right...)

65 Tinus Bosselaar

61 Theo Pahlplatz (famous Twente player in the 1970s)

53 Simon Tahamata

51 Gerald Vanenburg (the next Cruyff, the eternal talent and a very flashy player with a wide variety of tricks)

49 Rene van de Kerkhof

47 Piet van der Kuil

44 Sjaak Swart

38 Johnny Rep

35 Tonny van der Linden (also an inside-left)

31 Willy Brokamp (inside-left, very technically gifted player, a master of the free kick)

29 Kees Rijvers (the inside-right of the Magical Inside Trio)

24 Kick Smit (inside-left, 'the wanderer')

21 Bertus de Harder (on of the first to go abroad)

19 Coen Moulijn

13 Piet Keizer

7 Rob Rensenbrink

5 Faas Wilkes (the inside-left of the Magical Inside Trio)

3 Abe Lenstra (in the Dutch team nearly always the striker but his favourite position was the inside-left position and could operate as a outside-winger as well)

If somebody thinks I forgot one I can look it up.

Maybe he had a nice peek at Ajax, but after that it was soon "over" for him and so only had a pretty short presence at the top. I am still thankful for him making that cross to Ruud against Germany at the Euro 2004 but he only played 17 times for the national team. At Everton he was almost always a bench player if I remember correctly.

To call him one of the best is not realistic, but maybe you like him like I like van Vossen. A player does not have to be the best in order for you to like him seeing playing.

Actually I think a lot of people making top lists of players do it with quite a margin of bias also. Maybe they will use as a base year to year ranking lists etc., but even then you have to puzzle so much that personal bias will get into it. I saw a knowledgeable poster from United claim that Jaap Stam should be rated higher than Dennis Bergkamp. He was dead sure. Wonder where that came from

I have seen all games from Overmars for the NT and all from Robben. I have seen countless games from both on club level. Pretty hard to tell who I would choose. Both absolute great players.

It also feels a little bit inappropriate to me to compare them. They have both been great for my NT and therefor I love them both. It's like asking a parent what kid they love the most

the thing is with Van Der Meyde, i feel he left Ajax too early, and injury as well. but he only have 2 season shine at Ajax and the rest of his career is a downfall, he barely play for Everton, and was bad at Inter ( well most of the time )

realistically, yeah he;s not a world class, but he should have been, and he have that gift, he just made the wrong decision leaving Ajax

Overmars and Robben is just 2 good players, hard to compare, but Overmars is more technical + tactical player though, Robben is a pure winger, Overmars can be anywhere on the pitch and still own, well overall, a more complete player than Robben

Sorry for the kick but here is a really good television profile about Coen Moulijn, made in 1965 so before the 'Golden Era' started. At that time Moulijn was the poster boy of Dutch football thanks to good performances against England national team and many more.

http://www.geschiedenis24.nl/speler.program.7108432.html

At the end the journalist Herman Kuiphof, the Dutchies here know him, says the following as conclusion:

"The question whether he is the best left winger Holland has ever known is a question I can't remotely answer. Jan de Natris was also very good in his own age. And [Kees] Mijnders, Joop van Nellen, Koos van Gelder and what do you think about Bertus de Harder? Yes, that one was probably the best 'number 11' [traditional left winger] we had ever seen. But his best years took place in another era and therefore every comparison is pointless.

Maybe Moulijn played his most electrifying game at the age of 18, which he has in common with De Harder and others before him. Maybe he could have developed his abilities further if he had left Feyenoord in favor of a foreign competition such as Spain. The interest from abroad was big, like when he played a marvelous friendly against Barcelona. Barcelona wanted to have him, but Feyenoord blocked it.

By any standard, he is not the old fashioned Dutch player. Not the one who symbolizes the 'big boy, brave heart'. He is supple, fast, skilled and tricky. He is blessed with the suppleness of an Argentinian, a Brazilian, a Spaniard.

At the moment he is out of shape with issues, but someone like him will return in the foreseeable future."

Interesting and good summary because this good journalist mentions a few of the 'forgotten' national legends. Also nice that he briefly touches the dominant football philosophy until the 1960s, lets hope that these times will never return and someone like Leroy Fer will not be glorified.

The level of football journalism in these days also leaves a lot to be desired by the way.
